The room that TUSCON was led into was moderately large to say the least. Th=
e
ceiling was perhaps ten to fifteen feet above TUSCON=92s head and was per=
haps
thirty five to forty feet wide; the room itself was large enough to
ac=
commodate the largest of most transfomers. The walls and ceiling appeared
t=
o be made out of some sort of hyper dense purple hued metal that looked it
=
could withstand a full hit from GRIMLOCK without even a dent. There were no=

windows in this room, although there were other doors, all of them closed =
at
the moment.



The motif oft the chamber was a cross between a ship=92s =
bridge and perhaps a
medieval throne room. Computer consoles lined the wall=
s with small view
screens positioned above them. Against one of the far wal=
l a huge view
screen dominated nearly the entire wall and on it were depict=
ed different
scenes and chambers that TUSCON himself was unfamiliar with. H=
owever judging
by the similarities of motif, it might be safe to conclude t=
hat they were
other places within the same structure that TUSCON was now in=
.



In the center of the room hanging from the ceiling was glowing sphere =
that
glowed a strange combination of swirling black and purple, energy arci=
ng
along its surface. It was about the size of a basket ball =96 if basketb=
alls
existed at this point in human development - and was attached next to =
the
ceiling by a short metal pole. Directly below this was what would pass =
for a
throne or perhaps a captain=92s chair that sat up on a raised dais of=
 some
sort, a few stairs leading down to the floor level that TUSCON himsel=
f now
stood. On this chair a massive figure was seated, his size and power =
evident
even though the figure on it was seated and faced away from TUSCON.=




As TUSCON entered into the room the figure turned his chair to face him=
 and
then stood, it was obvious that he was head and shoulders larger than =
TUSCON
himself. This figure looked almost muscular the way his armor was se=
t on his
frame. He looked to be fully as large as OPTIMAL OPTIMUS or as lar=
ge as
HYDRAS!



http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nbwrpg/photos/album/30678285=
7/pic/706257948/view



At his side stood a comparatively smaller figure wh=
o was perhaps seven or
eight feet or so, standing maybe as tall as CHEETOR =
or some of the other
Maximals, however his presence is still powerful and c=
learly felt. He was
predominantly silver with purple armor at his shins and=
 chest. He had wing
like protrusions on his back and his cranial armor look=
ed almost like an
Incan chieftain's headdress.



http://groups.yahoo.com/g=
roup/nbwrpg/photos/album/306782857/pic/1016482216/view



GUILEDART stepped=
 forward and bowed down at the foot of the stairs,
seemingly not even willi=
ng to step on the same stair as the ones above.



=93Great Magamtron and L=
ord Saberback.=94 GUILDART said from his kneeling
position. =93We have brou=
ght this one to you for your pleasure.=94 His tone was
one of humility, as =
a servant before his lord.



The large figure on, MAGMATRON looked down at=
 TUSCON, his large size made to
appear even larger as he was standing on th=
at raised dais. =93Ahh yes. I have
had a chance to view your fighting prowe=
ss.=94 He said with a sardonic smile.
=93You amuse me, I think you will do =
well.=94 He smiled as he stroked his chin,
his gaze on TUSCON watchful and =
thoughtful, like a chess master watching a
new but inferior opponent.



HA=
RDHEAD and HYDRA said to TUSCON =93Kneel before Magmatron!=94 their weapons=

pointed directly at TUSCON=92s back!



(TAG)



Preston

--000e0cd4b306d8808804ad3d6dc8
